timeline.bodyText: I'm not really sure about the difference, but shouldn't we use writer.keyword here?

replies.bodyText: This is a copy-paste from Calcite. We had to copy the code from Calcite's SqlFloorFunction, because it doesn't have suitable constructors.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: We test infinities and NAN, we should also test -0.0f. Also in all other tests.
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Added missing tests
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Also all other tests need it I think, maybe all subclasses of SqlExpressionIntegrationTestSupport
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: -0.0f and -0.0d produces interesting results only in the case of ABS. Note that the test coverage is not meant to be exhaustive, because it will take too much time to tests all possible permutations and special values. Instead, these tests aimed to cover interesting scenarios that are specific for the given operator.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Float.MIN_VALUE is a positive number actually...

replies.bodyText: Added missing tests to CEIL/FLOOR test classes

timeline.bodyText: We miss a test that two invocations of rand() in a single query return different value. It can be in a single row or in two rows or in the where clause: to sample 10% of rows one would use WHERE rand()<0.1
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Added a test
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Shouldn't we also test SELECT rand(), rand() FROM map? Maybe also in the WHERE clause.
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: I do not think we need it. The function doesn't depend on the context of a row or specific placement in the query.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: I know it will work now, but the purpose of the test is to document the behavior so that it doesn't change in the future due to some optimization. It's easy to write such a test.
replies.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: Extended the test to invoke the function several times for a row
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: We can also do this if operand2 is a constant expression that is >=0
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: This is not trivial to implement, because the constant is often wrapped into a CAST operator due to type coercion.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Could you please give some examples of queries producing such literals wrapped into CAST? Usually, a literal cast should be either unnecessary or evaluated statically. If we are frequently producing such casts at runtime, that should be considered as a potential performance issue.
replies.author: taburet

timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: These classes form a tiny framework for expression testing. In this specific PR, they are not used, but more usages will be added in the subsequent PRs with predicates and other expressions.

timeline.bodyText: Might be better to name these FUNCTION_x
timeline.author: viliam-durina

replies.bodyText: We name them this way because the relevant classes all extend com.hazelcast.sql.impl.expression.Expression class. I.e. they are all expressions in a sense, that they accept one or more argument, and produce the result. There is no principal difference between, say, functions, predicates, or special operators such as CAST, CASE, etc.

+
+/**
+ * Function that accepts a DOUBLE argument and produces a DOUBLE result.
+ */
+public class HazelcastDoubleFunction extends SqlFunction {
+    public HazelcastDoubleFunction(String name) {
+        super(
+            name,
+            SqlKind.OTHER_FUNCTION,
+            ReturnTypes.DOUBLE_NULLABLE,
+            HazelcastInferTypes.DECIMAL_IF_UNKNOWN,

replies.bodyText:
Fixed in 95442d9
The same problem was for RAND - we inferred DECIMAL, while the function expected BIGINT.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.message: Removed unnecessary tests for Float.MIN_VALUE and Double.MIN_VALUE
Added missing test for numeric literals in single quotes for CEIL/FLOOR tests
Test for several rows for RAND
Fixed inference for double functions (DECIMAL -> DOUBLE) and RAND (DECIMAL -> BIGINT)

timeline.bodyText:
Looks like a proper way of doing this is:
InferTypes.explicit(singletonList(HazelcastTypeFactory.INSTANCE.createSqlType(SqlTypeName.DOUBLE)))

This basically tells Calcite that the function accepts only doubles, also there would be no need in the conversion performed in DoubleFunction.eval, something like ((Number) value).doubleValue() should do the trick, plain (double) value would not work since conversion between numeric types is not necessarily leading to CAST insertion in Calcite.
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: Applied the suggested fix
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.message: Changed operand type inference for double functions

timeline.bodyText: SQRT is missing in the actual code, are there some complications with it?
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText:
SQRT is out of scope, as mentioned in the PR description. Calcite converts SQRT to POWER. The latter is not very easy to implement and test, because it requires advanced inference rules, similar to multiply.
Fixed JavaDoc.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Changed to explicit inference
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Are conversions necessary here, if all the types are already should be inferred statically by Calcite?
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: IMO there is no much difference. Converters are safer than relying on Calcite. In most cases, the return type will be the same, so the converter will not do anything except for cast from Object to a concrete type.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: The whole idea of switching to static typing was to assign valid types statically and avoid runtime conversions as much as possible. Defensive usage of converters at runtime doesn't make it safer, it makes it more uncertain. If there are some bugs with type inference and/or implicit casts behavior for parameters of math functions, usage of converters will hide them, since converters are readily converting everything. And there are no tests similar to UnaryMinusTest verifying the actual types assigned to parameters of math functions to give confidence.
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: There were no idea to avoid runtime conversions. This specific expression works in a way that it can tolerate different inputs for so long, as values are convertible. It is not concerned with Calcite integration.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: operandType == resultType should be always true since the return type inference is defined as ReturnTypes.ARG0_NULLABLE for ROUND and TRUNCATE, it might make sense to convert it into a general assert for this method.
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: Changed to assert
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: This line may produce a cryptic conversion error since operand type checker for ROUND and TRUNCATE is defined as NUMERIC_OPTIONAL_INTEGER. That last INTEGER is referring to SqlTypeFamily.INTEGER (not to SqlTypeName.INTEGER) and that family refers to all integer types including BIGINT. Either the type checker should allow only the compatible types or some meaningful error message should be provided.
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: Fixed and tested in 5ce9f81
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.message: Added lenght overflow handling to ROUND/TRUNCATE

timeline.bodyText:
It might make sense to create Random once if seed is provided and use setSeed in eval instead of allocating a new Random on every invocation.
What it the semantics of seed? Calcite's SqlRandFunction and RandomFunction define it as "initializing the random number generator with seed on first call".
BTW, what thread safety level is expected for expressions? As far as I remember, Exec is not required to be thread safe and expressions belong to its state.
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: Naive question: why Random instead of SecureRandom?
replies.author: nfrankel

replies.bodyText:
@taburet seed could change from invocation to invocation. We do not know whether it should be used or not before the actual operand is processed. I would not complicate things, this is a micro-optimization for a function, which is mainly used for testing.
The state is not shared between expression instances. They are not thread-safe.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: @nfrankel This function doesn't have a requirement to be cryptographically strong, therefore we use the more performant implementation.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: @devozerov what about semantics of seed and implied thread safety for expressions?
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: Expressions do not have a shared state - does this answer the question?
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Does that mean there should be no state to share or the state is not shared between threads?
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: One expression instance is not meant to have any semantical influence on the results of other expressions. Expressions are not concerned with threading at all.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: To put it simple, can eval be invoked by the query execution engine from more than one thread simultaneously on the same expression instance?
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: No. Expressions are not thread-safe. A single instance is not meant to be executed by multiple threads simultaneously.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: Looks like there are no tests for boolean columns and parameters here and for other expressions as well.
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: Let's collect the list of missing test cases and add them separately. Subsequent PRs fixe more problems with conversions, so it would be a waste of time adding these tests in this PR.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Ticket: #17360
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Not sure how it does relate to problematic conversions, boolean-to-numeric conversion is prohibited currently and there are no plans I'm aware of to change that, it's just the tests missing, that should be easy to add them.
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: In this specific branch parameter conversions do not work properly - it allows conversions that are otherwise explicit only. Subsequent PRs fixes that.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText:
Moreover, we have broken type inference - it also allows conversions that are otherwise explicit (e.g. INT to VARCHAR). We do not have a solution for this at the moment, neither we know the exact error messages that we will have in the future.
That said, these corner cases should not be critical for beta IMO
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: Does that mean boolean can be converted to numeric for ABS in this PR?
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText: No, it can't. But the error message that appears in this branch is different, from what we will have after the next PR is ready.
replies.author: devozerov

replies.bodyText: In which next PR the message would change? It shouldn't be hard to add the tests in this PR and fix a couple of error message strings here and there later. The actual error messages are not important, the fact that we are failing while converting boolean to numeric is important.
replies.author: taburet

replies.bodyText:
In the next PR with predicates. Why should we spend time on writing tests only to rewrite them later? There is no BOOLEAN-specific logic in this PR, all expressions work the same way and rely on the existing expressions code base.
The more expressions I implement, the more bugs I found. This requires to me rewrite tests and spend precious time that we have before code freeze. We will easily add more tests after the code freeze.
Please do not follow the formal approach here. Our goal is to implement as many expressions as possible before the code freeze with sensible quality. In this specific case, we know for sure that there is no BOOLEAN-specific code, so the risk is minimal; and that the tests we write now will have to be rewritten afterwards, so it is definitely a waste of time.
replies.author: devozerov

timeline.bodyText: It might make sense to create a test for it in HazelcastInferTypesTest.
timeline.author: taburet

replies.bodyText:
Created a ticket for that: #17360
There is a high level of confidence that it works as expected because there are integration tests that cover this
replies.author: devozerov
